The best option in H3 is to use the 'Action Directory'. You can drop a 
'.seeds' file into the job's 'action' directory, and the crawler will 
notice the file, treat it the same as a start-of-crawl seeds file, then 
move the file (with a timestamped suffix) to the 'done' subdirectory. See:

https://webarchive.jira.com/wiki/display/Heritrix/Action+Directory

(ActionDirectory is an optional bean for H3 configurations, but our 
recommended default configuration already includes it.)

Note that because of order-of-discovery and path-of-discovery issues, 
adding seeds mid-crawl may not have the exact same effect as having them 
present at the start.

This is a subtle issue, and often not a major concern, but important to 
understand if concerned about the precision of your crawl scoping, and 
regularly modifying the crawl's effective scope after it starts.

To better understand, consider a site A, which has a several-links-deep 
page A', which redirects to page B'. Assume our default configuration.

If the root page of A is a seed, then our usual rules consider all other 
pages on A as being in-scope. We also rule-in URIs that appear necessary 
to render pages on A (included as IMG/SCRIPT/STYLE/FRAME sources or 
referenced inside Javascript strings), and URIs that are the immediate 
targets of redirects from pages on A (treat them "as if" they were the 
source URI).

Even if site B was not initially in-scope, page B' is ruled in-scope, 
and fetched (along with its own inline resources), when discovered via 
the redirect from A'. However, other pages on B, even if the target of 
A/@HREF links on page B', will not be crawled.

If you then, later in the crawl, add the root page of B, then from that 
point on all pages on B will be considered in-scope. However, page B' 
will not be reevaluated. If another link to it is discovered, that path 
is ignored -- because the target URI, B', was previously discovered (and 
crawled). If there are pages on B that can only be discovered through 
B', they will not be found. (If there are other paths to these pages, 
they will be found -- failing scope-testing once doesn't prevent a URI 
from being retested and enqueued later, only being previously enqueued 
prevents re-enqueueing.)

- Gordon @ IA
